summary:
The Security Council,
Recalling previous resolutions and statements on Burundi, particularly resolution 1375 (2001) and statements of 18 December 2002 and 23 December 2003,
Reaffirms strong commitment to Burundi's sovereignty, independence, territorial integrity and unity, and the principles of good-neighbourliness and non-interference. 
Reaffirms full support for the Arusha Peace and Reconciliation Agreement, 
calls on all Burundian parties to honour their commitments and assures them of its determination to support their efforts.
Encourages transitional institutions to enact laws required for the electoral process under the Arusha Agreement before 31 October 2004.
Takes note of ceasefire agreements, 
urges all parties to observe an immediate ceasefire, 
stressing the importance of Mr. Agathon Rwasa's Palipehutu-FNL participating in the peace process.
Condemns all acts of violence, human rights and international humanitarian law violations, 
particularly concerned by increasing incidents of rapes. 
Reaffirms determination to support efforts to bring perpetrators to justice, 
calls upon parties and transitional authorities to take measures to that end.
Expresses concern at the humanitarian situation, 
recalling parties' responsibility for civilian populations' security. 
Takes note of progress in preparing disarmament, demobilization and reintegration programme, 
calls on parties to commit themselves to that programme.
Expresses concern at the deteriorating economic situation, 
recognizing that any improvement in security should be matched by tangible economic and social benefits.
Welcomes conclusions of the Forum of Development Partners, 
calls on donors to honour their pledges.
Pays tribute to efforts made by the African Union and Regional Initiative, 
encourages the African Union to maintain a strong presence in Burundi. 
Welcomes efforts of the African Mission in Burundi (AMIB) and contributing countries.
Here is a concise summary of the Security Council document:

The Security Council:
Encourages efforts to train a joint Burundian protection unit to ensure security of transitional institutions' leaders.

Welcomes recommendations in the Secretary-General's report on Burundi and authorizes a 6-month peacekeeping operation, United Nations Operation in Burundi (ONUB), to support peace and national reconciliation under the Arusha Agreement.
